paper_title: Self-assembled g-C3N4 nanotubes/graphdiyne composite with enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction

catalyst.llm generation: g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes (CNtb) with sheet-like graphdiyne (GDY) composite
catalyst.source: In this work, g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes (CNtb) with sheet-like graphdiyne (GDY) composite are successfully prepared through a simple self-assembly method.
catalyst.context: In this work, g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes (CNtb) with sheet-like graphdiyne (GDY) composite are successfully prepared through a simple self-assembly method.The composite is proved to significantly improve the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers and the conductivity of the material, which consequently leads to enhanced performance towards photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.For the composite, the yields for CO and CH 4 are increased by 18-20 times, compared with pure CNtb.This work provides a new idea for the preparation of efficient g-C 3 N 4 photocatalysts in the future.

catalyst.source: The g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes/graphdiyne composite is obtained through a simple self-assemble process under ultrasonication.
catalyst.context: The preparation of g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes is based on a published literature with some modification 40.All of the reagents were used without further treatment.In a typical preparation process, 4 g of melamine was dispersed in 80 mL of deionized water under vigorously stirring for 2 h.After that, the mixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon lined autoclave and kept at 200 C for 12 h.The white precursor was washed several times with deionized water and dried in air at 60 C.Subsequently, the precursor was placed in a crucible, heated to 550 C at a rate of 2 C/min in air and kept for 4 h to obtain the sample. The graphdiyne is obtained from Changshui Huang's group, Qingdao Institute of Biomass Energy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences.The g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes/graphdiyne composite is obtained through a simple self-assemble process under ultrasonication.In brief, a certain amount of GDY was dispersed in 40 mL of N-methylpyrrolidone, and then exposed to ultrasonic irradiation for 30 min, which was named as solution A. A certain amount of CNtb was dispersed in 20 mL of N-methylpyrrolidone, ultrasonically dispersed for 30 min, and named as solution B; Solution B was added dropwise to solution A under stirring.The mixed solution was first further exposed to ultrasonic irradiation for 8 h, and then continuously mechanical stirring at 50 C for 12 h.The obtained sample was washed several times with deionized water and ethanol, and finally dried under vacuum at 60 C overnight.The obtained sample is named GDYCNtb-x, where x represents the mass ratio of GDY to CNtb. The X-ray diffraction pattern (XRD) of the synthesized sample was determined by an X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu-K Xray radiation (XRD Bruker AXS D8), and the diffraction angle range was 10-90.The microscopic morphology was measured by the field emission scanning electron microscope (Hitachi S-4800) and the field emission transmission electron microscope (JEM-2100F).UV-vis diffuse reflection absorption (DRS) is measured by Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere using BaSO 4 as the reference.The photoluminescence spectra (PL) are obtained by fluorescence spectrometer (FLS-980).The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of the samples were measured by a Micromeritics ASAP Kubo X1000 analyzer at liquid nitrogen temperature.The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained by the ThermoFisher ESCALAB 250 spectrometer.Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra was performed on a NEXUS 670 spectrometer, the scanning range is 400-4000 cm -1 .The surface potential of the samples was determined by measuring the Zeta potential (Zetasizer Nano ZS ZEN3600). The photoelectrochemical properties of the samples were investigated using an electrochemical workstation (CHI660E C18532, Chen Hua Instrument Co., Ltd.Shanghai), with platinum wire and Ag/AgCl (in saturated KCl) as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively, and phosphate buffer solution as the electrolyte.Usually, 1 mg of sample powder is dispersed into 1 mL of isopropanol solution, 10 L of Nafion solution is added, and then the mixture is sonicated for 3 h.50 L of above mixed solution was dripcoated onto a 1 1 cm FTO sheet, and form a working electrode after drying.The photocurrent test was performed at a constant voltage of 0.7 V, and the impedance test was performed at a voltage of 0 V. The experiment was carried out in an 80 mL closed quartz reactor.Generally, 20 mg catalyst was placed in the reactor, 100 L of deionized water was added, and the mixture of catalyst powder and water was stirred to spread the powder evenly onto the bottom of the reactor in order to maximize the interaction area with CO 2 .Then, the reactor was purged with CO 2 for 30 min to remove the other gases.After that, the reaction was carried out under the irradiation of a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a 420 nm filter.0.5 mL of gas was extracted from the reactor every 1 h.CO and CH 4 were measured by a GC-7920 gas chromatograph (equipped with FID detector and N 2 as carrier gas), and H 2 was measured by a GC-7806 gas chromatograph (equipped with TCD detector and Ar as carrier gas).

co-catalyst.context: In this work, g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes (CNtb) with sheet-like graphdiyne (GDY) composite are successfully prepared through a simple self-assembly method.The composite is proved to significantly improve the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers and the conductivity of the material, which consequently leads to enhanced performance towards photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.For the composite, the yields for CO and CH 4 are increased by 18-20 times, compared with pure CNtb.This work provides a new idea for the preparation of efficient g-C 3 N 4 photocatalysts in the future.

light source.context: In this work, g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes (CNtb) with sheet-like graphdiyne (GDY) composite are successfully prepared through a simple self-assembly method.The composite is proved to significantly improve the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers and the conductivity of the material, which consequently leads to enhanced performance towards photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.For the composite, the yields for CO and CH 4 are increased by 18-20 times, compared with pure CNtb.This work provides a new idea for the preparation of efficient g-C 3 N 4 photocatalysts in the future.

light source.source: UV-vis diffuse reflection absorption (DRS) is measured by Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere using BaSO 4 as the reference.
light source.context: The preparation of g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes is based on a published literature with some modification 40.All of the reagents were used without further treatment.In a typical preparation process, 4 g of melamine was dispersed in 80 mL of deionized water under vigorously stirring for 2 h.After that, the mixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon lined autoclave and kept at 200 C for 12 h.The white precursor was washed several times with deionized water and dried in air at 60 C.Subsequently, the precursor was placed in a crucible, heated to 550 C at a rate of 2 C/min in air and kept for 4 h to obtain the sample. The graphdiyne is obtained from Changshui Huang's group, Qingdao Institute of Biomass Energy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences.The g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes/graphdiyne composite is obtained through a simple self-assemble process under ultrasonication.In brief, a certain amount of GDY was dispersed in 40 mL of N-methylpyrrolidone, and then exposed to ultrasonic irradiation for 30 min, which was named as solution A. A certain amount of CNtb was dispersed in 20 mL of N-methylpyrrolidone, ultrasonically dispersed for 30 min, and named as solution B; Solution B was added dropwise to solution A under stirring.The mixed solution was first further exposed to ultrasonic irradiation for 8 h, and then continuously mechanical stirring at 50 C for 12 h.The obtained sample was washed several times with deionized water and ethanol, and finally dried under vacuum at 60 C overnight.The obtained sample is named GDYCNtb-x, where x represents the mass ratio of GDY to CNtb. The X-ray diffraction pattern (XRD) of the synthesized sample was determined by an X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu-K Xray radiation (XRD Bruker AXS D8), and the diffraction angle range was 10-90.The microscopic morphology was measured by the field emission scanning electron microscope (Hitachi S-4800) and the field emission transmission electron microscope (JEM-2100F).UV-vis diffuse reflection absorption (DRS) is measured by Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere using BaSO 4 as the reference.The photoluminescence spectra (PL) are obtained by fluorescence spectrometer (FLS-980).The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of the samples were measured by a Micromeritics ASAP Kubo X1000 analyzer at liquid nitrogen temperature.The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained by the ThermoFisher ESCALAB 250 spectrometer.Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra was performed on a NEXUS 670 spectrometer, the scanning range is 400-4000 cm -1 .The surface potential of the samples was determined by measuring the Zeta potential (Zetasizer Nano ZS ZEN3600). The photoelectrochemical properties of the samples were investigated using an electrochemical workstation (CHI660E C18532, Chen Hua Instrument Co., Ltd.Shanghai), with platinum wire and Ag/AgCl (in saturated KCl) as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively, and phosphate buffer solution as the electrolyte.Usually, 1 mg of sample powder is dispersed into 1 mL of isopropanol solution, 10 L of Nafion solution is added, and then the mixture is sonicated for 3 h.50 L of above mixed solution was dripcoated onto a 1 1 cm FTO sheet, and form a working electrode after drying.The photocurrent test was performed at a constant voltage of 0.7 V, and the impedance test was performed at a voltage of 0 V. The experiment was carried out in an 80 mL closed quartz reactor.Generally, 20 mg catalyst was placed in the reactor, 100 L of deionized water was added, and the mixture of catalyst powder and water was stirred to spread the powder evenly onto the bottom of the reactor in order to maximize the interaction area with CO 2 .Then, the reactor was purged with CO 2 for 30 min to remove the other gases.After that, the reaction was carried out under the irradiation of a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a 420 nm filter.0.5 mL of gas was extracted from the reactor every 1 h.CO and CH 4 were measured by a GC-7920 gas chromatograph (equipped with FID detector and N 2 as carrier gas), and H 2 was measured by a GC-7806 gas chromatograph (equipped with TCD detector and Ar as carrier gas).

light source.source: Fig. 3.The high resolution XPS spectra of (a) C 1s and (b) N 1s for CNtb and GDYCNtb-0.07;(c) UV-visible DRS spectra, (d) the PL spectra of CNtb and GDYCNtb-0.07.
light source.context: In summary, GDYCNtb composite are prepared using a simple self-assembly method.By introducing GDY, the absorption of the GDYCNtb in the visible light region is significantly enhanced.In addition, the addition of GDY enhances the conductivity of the material.At the same time, the good carrier mobility of GDY is conducive to promote the separation of photogenerated carriers, thereby improving the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction ability.After four cycles, the photocatalytic activity of the composite does not decrease significantly, proving the good stability of the composite.This work is also the first report to combine powder CNtb with GDY under a simple ultrasonication and stirring process, which provides a new idea for the preparation of other g-C 3 N 4 -based materials in the future. The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper. Fig. 1.(a) XRD patterns of photocatalysts GDY, CNtb and GDYCNtb, (b) Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of CNtb and GDYCNtb-0.07.Inset: pore size distribution for CNtb and GDYCNtb-0.07. Fig. 3.The high resolution XPS spectra of (a) C 1s and (b) N 1s for CNtb and GDYCNtb-0.07;(c) UV-visible DRS spectra, (d) the PL spectra of CNtb and GDYCNtb-0.07. Fig. 4. (a) The photocurrent responses and (b) EIS Nyquist plots for CNtb and GDYCNtb-0.07. Fig. 5.The CO (a) and CH 4 (b) evolution as a function of irradiation time over pure CNtb and GDYCNtb composites with different GDY to CNtb mass ratios.(c) further comparison of CO and CH 4 yield over different samples after 4 h of illumination ( 420 nm); and (d) cyclic photocatalytic performance of GDYCNtb-0.07 under long-term illumination with 420 nm filter. Conceptualization, Methodology, Formal analysis, Writing -original draft.Yuanyuan Liu: Resources, Writing -review editing, Supervision.Zeyan Wang: Validation, Investigation.Peng Wang: Resources, Investigation.Zhaoke Zheng: Formal analysis.Hefeng Cheng: Validation, Investigation.Xiaoyan Qin: Project administration, Investigation.Xiaoyang Zhang: Validation, Project administration.Ying Dai: Formal analysis, Software.Baibiao Huang: Resources, Writing -review editing, Supervision, Project administration. Journal of Alloys and Compounds 868 (2021) 159045 Scheme 1. Proposed mechanism of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction over GDYCNtb.C. Sun, Y. Liu, Z. Wang et al.Journal of Alloys and Compounds 868 (2021) 159045 This work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant numbers U1832145, 51972195, 21832005, 21972078, 11374190, and 51321091), Young Scholars Program of Shandong University (20506WLJH16, and 2020QNQT012), Taishan Scholar Foundation of Shandong Province, China, The Key Research and Development Program of Shandong Province (2019GGX103026), Project for Scientific Research Innovation Team of Young Scholar in Colleges and Universities of Shandong Province (2019KJA009).The authors also thank Professor Changshui Huang for kindly providing us the graphdiyne. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found in the online version at doi:10.1016/j.jallcom.2021.159045.

operation mode.source: 0.5 mL of gas was extracted from the reactor every 1 h.
operation mode.context: The preparation of g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes is based on a published literature with some modification 40.All of the reagents were used without further treatment.In a typical preparation process, 4 g of melamine was dispersed in 80 mL of deionized water under vigorously stirring for 2 h.After that, the mixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon lined autoclave and kept at 200 C for 12 h.The white precursor was washed several times with deionized water and dried in air at 60 C.Subsequently, the precursor was placed in a crucible, heated to 550 C at a rate of 2 C/min in air and kept for 4 h to obtain the sample. The graphdiyne is obtained from Changshui Huang's group, Qingdao Institute of Biomass Energy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences.The g-C 3 N 4 nanotubes/graphdiyne composite is obtained through a simple self-assemble process under ultrasonication.In brief, a certain amount of GDY was dispersed in 40 mL of N-methylpyrrolidone, and then exposed to ultrasonic irradiation for 30 min, which was named as solution A. A certain amount of CNtb was dispersed in 20 mL of N-methylpyrrolidone, ultrasonically dispersed for 30 min, and named as solution B; Solution B was added dropwise to solution A under stirring.The mixed solution was first further exposed to ultrasonic irradiation for 8 h, and then continuously mechanical stirring at 50 C for 12 h.The obtained sample was washed several times with deionized water and ethanol, and finally dried under vacuum at 60 C overnight.The obtained sample is named GDYCNtb-x, where x represents the mass ratio of GDY to CNtb. The X-ray diffraction pattern (XRD) of the synthesized sample was determined by an X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu-K Xray radiation (XRD Bruker AXS D8), and the diffraction angle range was 10-90.The microscopic morphology was measured by the field emission scanning electron microscope (Hitachi S-4800) and the field emission transmission electron microscope (JEM-2100F).UV-vis diffuse reflection absorption (DRS) is measured by Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere using BaSO 4 as the reference.The photoluminescence spectra (PL) are obtained by fluorescence spectrometer (FLS-980).The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of the samples were measured by a Micromeritics ASAP Kubo X1000 analyzer at liquid nitrogen temperature.The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained by the ThermoFisher ESCALAB 250 spectrometer.Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra was performed on a NEXUS 670 spectrometer, the scanning range is 400-4000 cm -1 .The surface potential of the samples was determined by measuring the Zeta potential (Zetasizer Nano ZS ZEN3600). The photoelectrochemical properties of the samples were investigated using an electrochemical workstation (CHI660E C18532, Chen Hua Instrument Co., Ltd.Shanghai), with platinum wire and Ag/AgCl (in saturated KCl) as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively, and phosphate buffer solution as the electrolyte.Usually, 1 mg of sample powder is dispersed into 1 mL of isopropanol solution, 10 L of Nafion solution is added, and then the mixture is sonicated for 3 h.50 L of above mixed solution was dripcoated onto a 1 1 cm FTO sheet, and form a working electrode after drying.The photocurrent test was performed at a constant voltage of 0.7 V, and the impedance test was performed at a voltage of 0 V. The experiment was carried out in an 80 mL closed quartz reactor.Generally, 20 mg catalyst was placed in the reactor, 100 L of deionized water was added, and the mixture of catalyst powder and water was stirred to spread the powder evenly onto the bottom of the reactor in order to maximize the interaction area with CO 2 .Then, the reactor was purged with CO 2 for 30 min to remove the other gases.After that, the reaction was carried out under the irradiation of a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a 420 nm filter.0.5 mL of gas was extracted from the reactor every 1 h.CO and CH 4 were measured by a GC-7920 gas chromatograph (equipped with FID detector and N 2 as carrier gas), and H 2 was measured by a GC-7806 gas chromatograph (equipped with TCD detector and Ar as carrier gas).
